fileTypes.//: Vscode's TextMate acknowledges "fileTypes" but doesn't do anything with it

patterns.comment: An array of `"injectionSelector"` is not officially supported by VSCode TextMate. But still happens to work because JavaScript
Negates the following negation `-`, group `()` or series of scopes `foo bar abc`
All non-functional characters are treated as whitespace. This includes whitespace ` ` and asterisk `*`
patterns.name: comment.injection.whitespace.tm

"patterns": [ ... ]

//: Causing us to deviate from VSCode TextMate
If a scopename is placed at the beginning of "name" and has leading dots `.`
The dots will be striped by `$1` and it will appear that `...keyword` matches the scopename `keyword`, highlighting it
We can *partially* correct this by putting another character in front of the first dot `.`
Sadly the beginning double quote `"` is the only one available to us. Space ` ` would have been nicer
and it ends up showing up in `Inspect Editor Tokens and Scopes`. Once again deviating from VSCode TextMate
However, I doubt anyone would create a scopename starting with a double quote `"` and leading dots `.`

patterns.comment: TextMate 2.0 does not split scopes on spaces in their grammar files. But does so in their theme files.
TextMate 2.0 does not split scopes on spaces in their grammar files. But does so in their theme files.
Special scopes that change the standard token type. eg. disables bracket matching

patterns.comment: An invalid capture group number does not convert, instead it stays as plaintext
${0:/upcase} ${000999:/downcase}

An array of `"captures"` is not officially supported by VSCode TextMate. But still happens to work because JavaScript
All normal "patterns" rules are allowed here. With the exception of "include". But only when they are paired with "patterns"
